titleproper.value: Preliminary Inventory to the Kenneth Neill Cameron Papers <num>TAM 186</num>

author.value: Collection processed by Molly Kovel, 1999; Peter Filardo, 2009

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-04-27T19:26:39</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value: Kenneth Neill Cameron (1908-1994), a Shelley scholar, best known for his four-volume <emph render="italic">Shelley and His Circle</emph>, was also the author of a biography of Joseph Stalin, and works on Marxist philosophy, world history, and ecology, and a volume of poetry. Cameron was a professor of English at Indiana University and later at New York University. The collection consists mainly of published and unpublished typescripts, including an incomplete autobiographical typescript, and correspondence, both editorial and personal. The unpublished typescripts include an incomplete autobiography, a biography of Enver Hoxha, Communist leader of Albania, several plays, and writings about several Communist leaders and heads of state. There are also articles, reviews, notes, reports, newspaper clippings, and various biographical materials, and materials related to his own political activities as a Communist, including his U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) file.

p.value: Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; Kenneth Neill Cameron Papers; TAM 185; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
Donated by Kenneth Neill Cameron in 1994 according to the terms of his last will and testament (1993). The accession number associated with this gift is 1993.010.

<list><item>See also, "Town and Gown: Excerpt from the Bloomington, Indiana Memoir of Kenneth Neill Cameron, Communist Academic in the Working Class Movement." (Peter Meyer Filardo, ed.) <emph render="italic">Labor History</emph>, 36, no. 4 (1995): 612-24.</item></list>

<emph render="bold">Series IV, Miscellaneous Unprocessed</emph>: This series contains published and unpublished writings and correspondence related thereto, some personal correspondence, including correspondence with Communist historian Herbert Aptheker, a folder relating to the W. Alphaeus Hunton College Teachers' Club of the CPUSA, and one relating to efforts to defend former East German Communists from prosecution. The manuscripts include an unpublished biography of Enver Hoxha, Communist leader of Albania, whole or partial drafts of several of his published works, chapter length published and unpublished writings on Nikolai Bukharin, Vladimir Lenin, Mao Zedung, sociobiology, and various Marxist-oriented historical and philosophical topics.

corpname.value: Communist Party of the United States of America

Topics include Marxism and literature; Marxist philosophy; an article on Nikolai Bukharin, articles critiquing "revisionism" and Gorbachev; correspondence with several friends and colleagues, including Herbert Aptheker; and a file on efforts to defend Erich Honecker and other former East German Communists from prosecution.</unittitle><unitdate normal="1980/1999" type="inclusive">1980s-1990s</unitdate><container id="aspace_9adcc2384d789dd78c2ab3b351dc0ab4" label="Mixed Materials" type="Box">8</container></did></c><c id="aspace_ref113" level="file"><did><unittitle>Writings, published and unpublished. Topics include Stalin, Mao Zedong, Enver Hoxha (Communist leader of Albania), Marxist philosophy, world history, ecology and Marxism.</unittitle><unitdate normal="1970/1989" type="inclusive">undated, 1970s-1980s</unitdate><container id="aspace_8236b86f4e06c10fedf4806bfe41d7f4" label="Mixed Materials" type="Box">9</container></did></c><c id="aspace_ref114" level="file"><did><unittitle>Writings, published and unpublished, and related correspondence. Most appear to be drafts, whole or partial, of his published books <emph render="italic">Atmospheric Destruction and Human Survival</emph> (1992), <emph render="italic">Marxism: A Living Science</emph> (1993), and <emph render="italic">Dialectical Materialism and Modern Science</emph> (1995). There is also a partial typescript for an unpublished book about Enver Hoxha; a folder titled "Factions" relating to the 1989-1991 internal struggle within the Communist Party USA; a folder containing several issues [1987-9] of, and correspondence relating to <emph render="italic">Red Academy</emph>, a publication of the W. Alphaeus Hunton College Teachers Club of the CPUSA. [The original issues have been separated for cataloging, with copies retained in the folder.]</unittitle><unitdate normal="1980/1999" type="inclusive">undated, 1980s-1990s</unitdate><container id="aspace_2ad7210fe5cfc088002f473b20d5800c" label="Mixed Materials" type="Box">10</container></did></c><c id="aspace_ref115" level="file"><did><unittitle>There is one large folder of correspondence, late 1940s-1980s; the rest of the box contains writings, published and unpublished, and related correspondence. Topics include Marxist theory and tactics, Lenin, Mao Zedong, Enver Hoxha, and sociobiology.</unittitle><unitdate normal="1940/1999" type="inclusive">1940s-1990s</unitdate><container id="aspace_b9a9e9354adcfbc0d153e943568e8ce4" label="Mixed Materials" type="Box">11</container></did></c><c id="aspace_ref116" level="file"><did><unittitle>Writings, published and unpublished, and related correspondence. Topics include Enver Hohxa, Mao Zedong. There are also several folders of personal correspondence, typically with friends and fellow academics, and some correspondence relating to an unfavorable review of his Shelley scholarship.</unittitle><unitdate normal="1970/1999" type="inclusive">1970s-1990s</unitdate><container id="aspace_478739c5ee5e722faaedba1d7c822471" label="Mixed Materials" type="Box">12</container></did></c></c>
